Pantsless Student Turns
nudist In Chemistry Lab
Did you ever see a student walking—pantsless in a raging snowstorm? Well, some did Monday
afternoon about four o'clock. Those
who saw the undergraduate walking
bare-legged, with the necessary
trousers missing, thought for a moment that a nudist had escaped from
the sunny shores of California.
An ill-fated flourish of a beaker
of concentrated nitric and sulfuric
acid was the whole cause. In the
chemical lab the student tore madly
at his pants. The acid had done its
damage and the undergrad stood

Martyr To Science

The man, whose name goes down
in the annals of science as a martyr,
had this to say:
"I was quietly doing my experiment when the beaker of concentrated acid slipped and some of the
contents splattered over my pants.

President Named Fellow Of
Institute Of Aeronautical Science
BOARD OF TRUSTEES
HOLDS MEETING

IN COMMEMORATION ADDRESS
•

Pronounces Invocation
And Benediction

DICKINSON SPEAKS
ON "LIBERALISM"

To Elect New Officers And
Discuss The Athletic
Situation
Appointment of Dr. Joseph S.
Ames as a fellow of the Institute of
Aeronautical Science was announced
recently by the President's office.
Dr. Ames was honored "for the
wise direction of the research work
of the National Advisory Committee of Aeronautics", of which he is
the chairman.
Board Of Trustees

The annual February meeting of
the Board of Trustees will be held
this morning at 10.30 a. m. This
meeting is always held on the day
following the exercises commemorating the inauguration of Daniel
Coit Gilman as first president of the
Johns Hopkins University.
At the meeting, to be held in the
Board of Trustees Room in Remsen Hall, officers will be elected for
the coming year.
It is expected that a discussion of
the athletic situation at the Hopkins
will take place. A sub-committee
will probably be appointed and asked
to investigate and make recommendations concerning the plea for reorganized sports.

SOPH-FROSH PLANS
GAINING HEADWAY
Although preparations for the
sophomore - freshman banquet
week have been suspended due to
the illness of Meade Johnson,
president of the sophomore class,
plans are now rapidly being carried out to make up for the delay.
Ballots will be distributed in
the post-office box of every member of the two classes before next
Wednesday. These ballots will
serve as a check-up of class sentiment for or against a combined
sophomore and freshman dance.
Should Express Opinion

is incumbent upon all members
of both classes to express their
approval or disapproval of this
proposal and to return the ballots
to the post-office as soon as possible. The officers of both classes
wish to emphasize, the importance of complete cooperation as
the only manner in which everyone can be satisfied.
It

Cotillion Doard Oars
Outsiders At Dances
An attempt to make the Cotillion Dances more exclusive will
begin tomorrow night when the
board will hold the first of a series of trial Invitation Dances at
Levering Hall from 9 to 12, with
the Ramblers furnishing the music, according to Lou Reuling
who has charge of the affair this
week.
Invitations will be sent to a
select list of outsiders and all
Hopkins students, faculty and
alumni are invited.
This move was motivated by
the appearance, at the dances, of
undesirables, and the board figures they can attract more Hopkins men by making the dances
closed affairs.
Subscription will be $1.

Appeals For Funds To Restore Budgets And Employ Scholars

Lists Dangers Which Movement Is Likely To
Encounter
By Melvin Goldberg
Appealing "for what may properly be called emergency support",
Dr. Joseph S. Ames, president of
the Hopkins, in his annual address
delivered yesterday at the Peabody
Conservatory Auditorium in commemoration of the fifty-eighth anniversary of the inauguration of Daniel Coit Gilman as the first president
of the Johns Hopkins University,
declared that the funds "would be
used first to restore the budgets of
all departments of the University
to their condition of a few years
ago, and secondly, to provide opportunity for the employment of
our group of young scholars."
An address by Dr. John S. Dick—Courtesy, The Sun papers inson, Assistant Secretary of ComREV. DONALD FRANK FENN
merce, entitled "The Ordeal of
Liberalism", and the presentation
to the University of a portrait of
Dr. Westal W. Willoughby, professor emeritus of political science,
also featured the exercises. The
musical program was under the direction of Philip S. Morgan and
was presented by the Johns HopExhibition Includes Wie- kins Orchestra, Bart Wirtz, conland Holographs And
ductor.

J. H. U. CELEBRATION
FEATURES LUNCHEON,
RARE BOOK DISPLAY
First Editions

Holographs and first editions' of
the famous German author, Christoph Martin Wieland, loaned by Dr.
William Kurrelmeyer, professor of
German, for an exhibition in the
reading room of the Hopkins Library, were on display following
President Joseph S. Ames' annual
Commemoration Day reception.
The president's reception followed
the exercises at the Peabody Conservatory and guests then adjourned
to Gilman Hall, where a buffet
luncheon was served. Those in the
receiving line included Dr. Ames,
Mrs. Baldwin, Dr. Dickinson, and
Mr. and Mrs. Blanchard Randall.
The Johns Hopkins press displayed its publications of the past
year, and Dr. William F. Albright,
Spence professor of Semitic languages, loaned a collection of ancient relics.

Dr. Willoughby Praised
Xy Dr. Hart At dxercises
Dr. James Hart, associate professor of political science, yesterday described Dr. W. W. Willoughby as "a gentleman and a
scholar, and one who has aptly
been called the dean of American
political scientists."
In presenting to the University
a portrait of his retired colleague
on behalf of "his/ students, hit
colleagues, and his friends", Dr.
Hart gave a brief characterization of Dr. Willoughby and an
account of his work.
"As a teacher', Dr. Hart said,
"Professor Willoughby has been
distinguished by his eminent fairness, by his successful pursuit of
the policy of encouraging students, in his own expressive
phrase, to work out their own
academic salvation, by his emphasis upon the grasp of basic
ideas rather than the conning of
isolated facts, and by his inspiring example of achievement."

Appeals For Money

"My address is in reality an appeal for money, an appeal for new
endowments and for emergency
gifts at the present moment," Dr.
Ames stated. He continued, "A
university such as the Hopkins is
not alone essential for the maintenance of civilization but is in reality
the essential element in the processes which are evidence of civilization."
"In order for a university to accomplish its purpose and to fulfill
these responsibilities it must have
the proper facilities and it must have
the necessary faculties to enable
them to pursue their studies and to
train their students.
Financial Stress Cited

"All universities today feel the
stress of the financial situation and
are struggling to maintain their existence or at least to maintain their
efficiency. The salaries of the members of the faculties have been reduced seriously and all appropriations for the support of laboratories and of scientific expeditions have
been reduced beyond what one
would call the danger point. A
university cannot continue and
should not be allowed to continue
under such circumstances."
As for those who have just completed their years of training, Dr.
Ames said "that unless some action
is taken immediately not only will
they who are the hope for the future disappear from the intellectual
world but also other young men and
women who are planning to devote
themselves to an intellectual life
will not begin their studies or continue them. Unless these young
people are provided for in some way
there will be a break in civilization.
"There is but one solution to
meet the difficulty of the present
emergency and that is to give to a
group of universities, in which I
should include the Johns Hopkins
University, large sums of money
so that they can provide proper oc(Continued on Page 4, Col. 4)

President Named Fellow Of
Institute Of Aeronautical Science
BOARD OF TRUSTEES
HOLDS MEETING

IN COMMEMORATION ADDRESS
•

Pronounces Invocation
And Benediction

DICKINSON SPEAKS
ON "LIBERALISM"

To Elect New Officers And
Discuss The Athletic
Situation
Appointment of Dr. Joseph S.
Ames as a fellow of the Institute of
Aeronautical Science was announced
recently by the President's office.
Dr. Ames was honored "for the
wise direction of the research work
of the National Advisory Committee of Aeronautics", of which he is
the chairman.
Board Of Trustees

The annual February meeting of
the Board of Trustees will be held
this morning at 10.30 a. m. This
meeting is always held on the day
following the exercises commemorating the inauguration of Daniel
Coit Gilman as first president of the
Johns Hopkins University.
At the meeting, to be held in the
Board of Trustees Room in Remsen Hall, officers will be elected for
the coming year.
It is expected that a discussion of
the athletic situation at the Hopkins
will take place. A sub-committee
will probably be appointed and asked
to investigate and make recommendations concerning the plea for reorganized sports.

SOPH-FROSH PLANS
GAINING HEADWAY
Although preparations for the
sophomore - freshman banquet
week have been suspended due to
the illness of Meade Johnson,
president of the sophomore class,
plans are now rapidly being carried out to make up for the delay.
Ballots will be distributed in
the post-office box of every member of the two classes before next
Wednesday. These ballots will
serve as a check-up of class sentiment for or against a combined
sophomore and freshman dance.
Should Express Opinion

is incumbent upon all members
of both classes to express their
approval or disapproval of this
proposal and to return the ballots
to the post-office as soon as possible. The officers of both classes
wish to emphasize, the importance of complete cooperation as
the only manner in which everyone can be satisfied.
It

Cotillion Doard Oars
Outsiders At Dances
An attempt to make the Cotillion Dances more exclusive will
begin tomorrow night when the
board will hold the first of a series of trial Invitation Dances at
Levering Hall from 9 to 12, with
the Ramblers furnishing the music, according to Lou Reuling
who has charge of the affair this
week.
Invitations will be sent to a
select list of outsiders and all
Hopkins students, faculty and
alumni are invited.
This move was motivated by
the appearance, at the dances, of
undesirables, and the board figures they can attract more Hopkins men by making the dances
closed affairs.
Subscription will be $1.

Appeals For Funds To Restore Budgets And Employ Scholars

Lists Dangers Which Movement Is Likely To
Encounter
By Melvin Goldberg
Appealing "for what may properly be called emergency support",
Dr. Joseph S. Ames, president of
the Hopkins, in his annual address
delivered yesterday at the Peabody
Conservatory Auditorium in commemoration of the fifty-eighth anniversary of the inauguration of Daniel Coit Gilman as the first president
of the Johns Hopkins University,
declared that the funds "would be
used first to restore the budgets of
all departments of the University
to their condition of a few years
ago, and secondly, to provide opportunity for the employment of
our group of young scholars."
An address by Dr. John S. Dick—Courtesy, The Sun papers inson, Assistant Secretary of ComREV. DONALD FRANK FENN
merce, entitled "The Ordeal of
Liberalism", and the presentation
to the University of a portrait of
Dr. Westal W. Willoughby, professor emeritus of political science,
also featured the exercises. The
musical program was under the direction of Philip S. Morgan and
was presented by the Johns HopExhibition Includes Wie- kins Orchestra, Bart Wirtz, conland Holographs And

J. H. U. CELEBRATION
FEATURES LUNCHEON,
RARE BOOK DISPLAY
First Editions

Holographs and first editions' of
the famous German author, Christoph Martin Wieland, loaned by Dr.
William Kurrelmeyer, professor of
German, for an exhibition in the
reading room of the Hopkins Library, were on display following
President Joseph S. Ames' annual
Commemoration Day reception.
The president's reception followed
the exercises at the Peabody Conservatory and guests then adjourned
to Gilman Hall, where a buffet
luncheon was served. Those in the
receiving line included Dr. Ames,
Mrs. Baldwin, Dr. Dickinson, and
Mr. and Mrs. Blanchard Randall.
The Johns Hopkins press displayed its publications of the past
year, and Dr. William F. Albright,
Spence professor of Semitic languages, loaned a collection of ancient relics.

Dr. Willoughby Praised
Xy Dr. Hart At dxercises
Dr. James Hart, associate professor of political science, yesterday described Dr. W. W. Willoughby as "a gentleman and a
scholar, and one who has aptly
been called the dean of American
political scientists."
In presenting to the University
a portrait of his retired colleague
on behalf of "his/ students, hit
colleagues, and his friends", Dr.
Hart gave a brief characterization of Dr. Willoughby and an
account of his work.
"As a teacher', Dr. Hart said,
"Professor Willoughby has been
distinguished by his eminent fairness, by his successful pursuit of
the policy of encouraging students, in his own expressive
phrase, to work out their own
academic salvation, by his emphasis upon the grasp of basic
ideas rather than the conning of
isolated facts, and by his inspiring example of achievement."

Appeals For Money

"My address is in reality an appeal for money, an appeal for new
endowments and for emergency
gifts at the present moment," Dr.
Ames stated. He continued, "A
university such as the Hopkins is
not alone essential for the maintenance of civilization but is in reality
the essential element in the processes which are evidence of civilization."
"In order for a university to accomplish its purpose and to fulfill
these responsibilities it must have
the proper facilities and it must have
the necessary faculties to enable
them to pursue their studies and to
train their students.
Financial Stress Cited

"All universities today feel the
stress of the financial situation and
are struggling to maintain their existence or at least to maintain their
efficiency. The salaries of the members of the faculties have been reduced seriously and all appropriations for the support of laboratories and of scientific expeditions have
been reduced beyond what one
would call the danger point. A
university cannot continue and
should not be allowed to continue
under such circumstances."
As for those who have just completed their years of training, Dr.
Ames said "that unless some action
is taken immediately not only will
they who are the hope for the future disappear from the intellectual
world but also other young men and
women who are planning to devote
themselves to an intellectual life
will not begin their studies or continue them. Unless these young
people are provided for in some way
there will be a break in civilization.
"There is but one solution to
meet the difficulty of the present
emergency and that is to give to a
group of universities, in which I
should include the Johns Hopkins
University, large sums of money
